The large increase in the thermal stability of the epoxy resin can be attributed to a two-fold mechanism: (i) the filler reinforces and stabilizes the epoxy resin and, being much more thermally inert, improves the endurance to heat of the organic matrix; (ii) when the resin is reinforced by functionalized fillers, the establishment of a large number of covalent bonds between resin and fillers promotes a sort of vulcanization among the organic domains.
For common glasses (n ∼1.46–1.65) SiO2 turns out to be most suitable because the required porosities around 50% may provide a satisfactory mechanical stability.

Encouraging results were obtained using different textured thin films (silica, metal oxides, fluorides); further improvement and demonstration of the effectiveness and durability of the coatings will support their deployment in commercial PV projects.
